2.12   Compliance Audits
PSM/RMP compliance audits are conducted at least every three years to verify that the PSM/RMP procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed.  The compliance audits are conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  Compliance audit reports are prepared.  Responses to the audits are managed, and deficiency corrections are documented.  The two most recent audit reports are retained.
3.0   Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
In addition to the release prevention program activities, safety features have been designed for all units to:
*Quickly detect a release;
*Contain/control a release; and
*Reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.
3.1   Release Detection
Detectors with alarms are located strategically throughout the process area.
3.2 Release Containment/Control
The containment and control methods utilized to prevent migration to the environment from a release are:
*Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases;
*Redundant equipment and instrumentation (i.e. uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pump); and
*Atmospheric relief devices.
3.3 Release Mitigation
The effects of releases are mitigated by:
*Use of fire suppression and extinguishing systems;
*Maintaining properly trained emergency response personnel;
*Use of personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus);
*Availability of fixed and mobile firefighting equipment; and
*Construction of blast-resistant buildings to help protect control systems and personnel.

2.9   Mechanical Integrity
Ineos has programs to maintain the ongoing mechanical integrity of process equipment.  The programs include written procedures, training, inspection and testing, correction of equipment deficiencies and quality assurance.
2.10   Incident Investigation / Accident Release History
Neither the Port nor Ineos has experienced an accidental release of a regulated substance in the past five years which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  It is the policy of the Port and Ineos that all accidents, unsafe conditions, and near misses are investigated, and remedial activities identified and implemented to prevent a reoccurrence of the condition.
2.11   Emergency Planning and Response
Emergency procedures are designed and implemented to minimize an employee's exposure to a hazardous chemical release, protect the environment and surrounding community, contain and/or neutralize a spill or release, and to ensure consistent standards are applied during a release within the plant boundary.  The emergency procedures for the Port facility are updated and tested on an annual basis to ensure the plan stays current and will accomplish all of the desired results.
The overall emergency response program is coordinated with the Calhoun County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The Port has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., local fire department). 
Ineos has a trained Emergency Response Team consisting of approximately 72 employees.  The team trains on a quarterly basis with emergency res

ety systems and their functions.
The operating procedures are readily accessible to employees on the process units and are reviewed as often as necessary to ensure they reflect current operating practice.  Procedures are routinely reviewed for content at least every three years depending on the criticality of the procedure as determined by the Area Managers or their designees.  Procedures are also modified and updated as needed as part of Management of Change.  Each Area Manager certifies annually that the operating procedures are current and accurate for process units within their area of responsibility.
The Area Manager is responsible for maintaining operating procedures for their department.  The Safety, Health and Environmental (SHE) Manager is assigned to maintain written safe work practices site wide.  The Area Managers are responsible for ensuring employees and contractors apply safe work practices in their departments.
2.6   Training
Employees involved in handling hazardous chemicals receive both safety training and process unit specific training.  Safety training includes safety and health hazards and safe work practices.  Unit specific training includes process specific training including operating procedures and emergency operations.  Periodic reviews of safety and environmental issues are conducted.
The Area Managers ensure employees within their areas of responsibility receive the training and qualification required for the employee's position assignments.
2.7   Contractors
Contract employees undergo training that covers hazards, emergency action and safe work practices.  The content of the training is determined by the Port and Ineos prior to allowing work by contractors on Port property.
2.8   Pre-Startup Safety Review
Ineos performs pre-startup safety reviews for both new and modified facilities.  It is the responsibility of those employees leading the change for small projects and of the project manager for large projects to ensure pre-star

rocedures, including those required by PSM, the RMP and general Port policies.  All employees are properly trained in the applicable safety practices, policies and procedures to safely conduct the activities of their job assignments and to respond to emergency events.
2.3   Process Safety Information
Ineos has a compilation of process safety information (PSI).  The PSI is available for conducting process hazards analyses.  The PSI includes:
*SDS information pertaining to the hazards of the chemicals used or produced by the processes;
*Process technology information including block flow diagrams or simplified process flow diagrams, process chemistry, maximum intended inventory, safe upper and lower limits and other information included in operating manuals and Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs); and
*Equipment information including P&IDs, electrical classification, relief system design and design basis, ventilation systems, safety systems, material and energy balances for new processes and equipment.
Controlled copies of the PSI documents are kept in the department responsible for them.  The PSI documents are maintained through application of the Ineos Management of Change Procedure.  Management of Change also involves a technical review that ensures and documents how changes in equipment comply with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.  It is the policy of Ineos that all applicable equipment is designed, maintained, inspected, tested and operated in a safe manner.
For new processes, a project change procedure is utilized for construction until construction is complete and authorized for commission, at which time the process becomes subject to the Management of Change procedure.
It is the responsibility of all personnel who lead activities involving PSI to ensure the applicable PSI is compiled and updated in accordance with OSHA PSM, the EPA RMP and the Management of Change Procedure.

RMP compliance is the responsibility of the Port Director.  The Port Director works in cooperation with the Ineos Plant Manager who is in direct consultation with the Ineos Process Safety Engineer.  The Ineos Process Safety Engineer provides technical expertise for process safety, communicates requirements to appropriate manufacturing managers, and coordinates policies and procedures to meet process safety requirements in support of the manufacturing areas.  Because the day-to-day operations at the Port facility associated with the RMP-regulated chemicals are the responsibility of Ineos, the Prevention Program was developed by Ineos, including the Process Hazard Analyses, Process Safety Information compilation, Standard Operating Procedures, Inspection and Testing procedures, and other safety-related programs.  Due to the nature of the owner/operator relationship the Port and Ineos collaborate for, emergency planning and response procedure development.  Port employees and Ineos employees who are assigned to Port operations undergo operating and emergency response training specific to the potential hazards related to management of acrylonitrile and ammonia at the Port.

2020 RMP Executive Summary

Calhoun Port Authority
	Port of Port Lavaca - Point Comfort
	EPA Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary
December 2020

1.0	Introduction

1.1   Relationship of Owner and Operator
The Port of Port Lavaca - Point Comfort (Port), directed by the Calhoun Port Authority, is the owner of the facility.  The portion of the Port facility that is subject to 40 CFR Part 68 Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations is operated by INEOS Nitriles, hereafter referred to as Ineos.  The RMP incorporates the release prevention, emergency response, and training provisions of both the owner and operator, since these two entities coordinate implementation of on-site procedures to ensure that both Port and site Ineos employees are properly prepared to prevent and respond to emergencies.
1.2   Owner History
The Port was constructed in the 1950s and designed to accommodate the transfer of chemicals and petrochemicals between ship or barge traffic and pipelines connected directly to remote client facilities.  In 1998, a major expansion of the Port was initiated to accommodate Ineos material transfers and storage.  An additional tank was commissioned in 2004.  The Port owns all equipment used to transfer and store chemicals at the facility, and Ineos is responsible for operation of the equipment to properly manage the chemicals.
1.3   Operator History
The process used to produce Ineos products involves the storage of quantities of listed hazardous chemicals that require application of Process Safety Management (PSM) as outlined  in OSHA 29 CFR Part 1910 and the RMP regulations.  Ineos has an outstanding environmental record and , and is a participant of the Clean Texas 2000 initiative.  
1.4  Regulated Substances Handled
The handling of acrylonitrile and ammonia are covered under this RMP.
